situation: Given a strong premise (premise 1), it is possible to derive a par-
ticular conclusion, but this strong premise is subject to criticism and there-
fore must be modified. When the premise is modified as in 1*, it no longer
supports the original conclusion that the person presenting the argument
wishes to establish.
The argument does not stop here. A defender of abortion might reply in
a number of ways. Some theory of fairness might be developed to argu
